question.title: Dealing with 16 bit characters using sun.misc.Unsafe

node.contents: If i need to put a character 0-127 to some memory address, in order to prevent out of range chars, i do this

astNode.text: If i need to put a character 0-127 to some memory address, in order to prevent out of range chars, i do this

elements.contents: if (0 != (c & 0xFF80)) { throw new RuntimeException("Only Ascii characters are supported. 0-127."); } else { // Since Java's chars are 16 bits long, i cast it // to byte (8 bits) and then `putByte()` UNSAFE.putByte(address, (byte) c); }

comments.text: // Since Java's chars are 16 bits long, i cast it // to byte (8 bits) and then `putByte()` UNSAFE.putByte(address, (byte) c); }

node.contents: When my test checks what's in that memory

astNode.text: When my test checks what's in that memory

elements.contents: char c1 = Ascii.a; asciiEncoder.encode(address, c1); assertThat(unsafe.getChar(address), is(c1));

units.rawText: char c1 = Ascii.a; asciiEncoderencode(address, c1); assertThat(unsafe.getChar(address), is(c1));

node.contents: This test seems to pass and fail on some machines. Let me repeat that - this works on some MACs and not the others and some Windows and not the others.

astNode.text: This test seems to pass and fail on some machines. Let me repeat that - this works on some MACs and not the others and some Windows and not the others.

node.contents: What is failing? Character different to 'a' is returned.

astNode.text: What is failing? Character different to 'a' is returned.

node.contents: As i understand it, this is possible if upon allocation, memory is not cleaned up, but does not this take care of this?

astNode.text: As i understand it, this is possible if upon allocation, memory is not cleaned up, but does not this take care of this?

elements.contents: @Before public void setUp() { address = unsafe.allocateMemory(64); // Isn't this mem clean? }

node.contents: If i change this to 8 bits, test passes always

astNode.text: If i change this to 8 bits, test passes always

node.contents: It pays to RTFM. Thanks hoaz! Thanks a lot!

astNode.text: It pays to RTFM. Thanks hoaz! Thanks a lot!

node.contents: Allocates a new block of native memory, of the given size in bytes. The contents of the memory are uninitialized; they will generally be garbage. The resulting native pointer will never be zero, and will be aligned for all value types. Dispose of this memory by calling #freeMemory , or resize it with #reallocateMemory .

astNode.text: Allocates a new block of native memory, of the given size in bytes. The contents of the memory are uninitialized; they will generally be garbage. The resulting native pointer will never be zero, and will be aligned for all value types. Dispose of this memory by calling #freeMemory , or resize it with #reallocateMemory .

node.contents: Which means when you put byte there and read char back you get extra byte of garbage.

astNode.text: Which means when you put byte there and read char back you get extra byte of garbage.
